channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Respite, Then Mayhem, as Qaeda-Aligned Militants Fight for Key Iraqi Cities
item.description: After what appeared to be a morning lull on Friday, explosions and new casualties were reported in Falluja and Ramadi, two of Iraq’s most important cities.
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Armed tribesmen and Iraqi police officers stood guard on Thursday as clashes raged in Ramadi, west of Baghdad.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel and U.S. Test Interceptor Missile
item.description: The Israel and the United States carried out a second test of the advanced Arrow 3 antiballistic missile system over the Mediterranean Sea.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: World War II Bomb Kills One Person in Germany
item.description: A bulldozer operator set off the bomb during construction work in Euskirchen, near Bonn, the former capital, wounding at least 13 people.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS COTTRELL

item.title: World Brief | Europe: Daughter of Palestinian Envoy Killed in Czech Republic Suspects Foul Play
item.description: The daughter of Jamal al-Jamal, who was killed this week in an explosion at his home in Prague, said she believed he was murdered.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: The Lede: Stranded Antarctic Ship Story, Like the Ice, Will Not Let Go
item.description: The stranded ship Akademik Shokalskiy only had five days of food left when a Chinese helicopter rescued passengers. Now, the rescuers themselves may need to be rescued.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Puppet Called Terrorist Mouthpiece
item.description: Egypt’s crackdown on support for the Muslim Brotherhood has turned surreal as prosecutors agreed to investigate the allegation that a puppet in a phone ad was sending coded instructions to Islamist terrorists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and LIAM STACK

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Complex Effort for Antarctic Rescue
item.description: Video and images shared on social media show the long-awaited rescue of the 52 passengers of a Russian ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, which has been trapped in ice off the coast of Antarctica since Dec. 24.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: India Ink: A Hunting Community in Nagaland Takes Steps Toward Conservation
item.description: In 2012, people in the northeastern state killed about 150,000 federally protected Amur falcons. In 2013, the number dropped to zero, after a campaign by the state and nonprofit groups to promote the value of wildlife.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA SINHA

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 3
item.description: A vendor preparing tea at a roadside stall in old Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man preparing tea at his roadside stall on a cold winter morning in old Delhi.

item.title: Despite Protests, Thailand Says February Vote Will Go Ahead
item.description: The election commission ignored the demands of antigovernment demonstrators Friday and said elections would go ahead on Feb. 2 despite efforts to sabotage them.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: After Fleeing Violence, Many Indian Muslims Refuse to Return Home
item.description: Four months after a spasm of religious violence in the state of Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 15,000 displaced Muslims remain in tent cities, not believing it is safe to return.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and BETWA SHARMA

item.title: Aid Crisis in Central African Republic Worsens, U.N. Says
item.description: Fighting has forced more than 935,000 people to flee their homes, the United Nations refugee agency said, and it is making it harder to deliver relief.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: After Antarctic Drama, Chinese Rescue Ship Is Threatened by Ice
item.description: The Snow Dragon, a Chinese vessel, requested help and an Australian icebreaker was placed on standby in case it became icebound.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Chinese Copter Rescues 52 From Ship in Antarctic Ice
item.description: The evacuation of the 52 passengers began after more than a week of attempts to approach the stranded research vessel, the Akademik Shokalskiy.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A helicopter from the nearby Chinese icebreaker Xue Long arrived to pick up the first batch of passengers from the stranded Russian ship Akademik Shokalskiy.

item.title: Thatcher Considered Using Military During 1984 Miners’ Strike
item.description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher considered calling out the British military to transport vital supplies during the strike, which became a defining confrontation of the Thatcher era, according to newly released documents.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Prime Minister Rules Out Third Term
item.description: Manmohan Singh said Friday that he would not be India’s next prime minister if his Congress Party-led coalition wins national elections scheduled for this spring.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Raid ‘Fortress’ of Drug Production in South China
item.description: The police arrested 182 suspects in a raid on a village in Guangdong Province suspected of supplying as much as one-third of China’s domestically produced supply of methamphetamine.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI
item.media:description: Police officers carrying away crystal meth seized in a raid on Boshe village.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: David Der-wei Wang on C.T. Hsia, Chinese Literary Critic
item.description: C.T. Hsia, who died in New York on Dec. 29 aged 92, was a cosmopolitan scholar who established a Chinese literary canon in the West, said his friend and colleague David Der-wei Wang.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: C.T. Hsia, right, with his wife, Della Hsia, and David Der-wei Wang at a restaurant in 2013.

item.title: U.S. Orders Evacuation of Staff Members From Embassy in South Sudan
item.description: The moved appeared to reflect a somber assessment of the country’s prospects, even as warring factions were said to have opened preliminary talks.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Hull Journal: As the Working Poor Become More Common in Britain, So Does Hunger
item.description: Five years of economic weakness, austerity and rising prices have left a mark, with at least 500,000 people in Britain reliant on food aid, three times more than a year ago.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Cambodian Police Fire on Protesters as Clashes Turn Violent
item.description: Military police officers killed at least three people, officials said, as protests against the decades-old rule of Prime Minister Hun Sen entered a volatile new phase.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Attack on Chinese Consulate Puts U.S. on Defensive
item.description: The New Year’s Day arson attack in San Francisco has prompted Chinese media to criticize United States security measures, as American officials have vowed to apprehend those responsible.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Wang Chuan, spokesman for the Chinese consulate, spoke with reporters in front of the consulate's scorched entrance on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Downed Balloon, China and Japan Cooperate
item.description: A Chinese balloonist who attempted to land on a disputed islet in the East China Sea was rescued by the Japanese Coast Guard, a rare peaceful resolution in fiercely contested waters.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Japan Coast Guard/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The hot-air balloon was spotted in the East China Sea, near islands disputed by China and Japan.

item.title: Hezbollah Moving Long-Range Missiles From Syria to Lebanon, an Analyst Says
item.description: The Shiite militia has been moving long-range missiles to Lebanon from bases inside Syria, according to an Israeli national security analyst, who said the missiles could strike deep inside his country.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: U.S. Military Ship Readied for Mission to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Weapons
item.description: The entire process, which officials said they hoped would begin within the next two weeks, would take roughly 90 days to complete, allowing for weather and other factors.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:description: The Cape Ray, part of the maritime reserve fleet in Portsmouth, Va., awaits orders to collect 700 tons of Syria’s lethal chemical weapons and destroy them at sea.
